The purity of superior precepts subsumes the second ground.
The purity of superior concentration subsumes the third ground.
The purity of superior wisdom subsumes the fourth ground and above, as it becomes increasingly sublime in each subsequent ground.

How do the eleven aspects subsume all the grounds?
That is to say, all bodhisattvas first, on the ground of resolute practice,
through extremely well-cultivated resolute acceptance in accordance with the ten practices of the Dharma,
surpass that ground and realize entry into the bodhisattva's correct nature, which is free from birth.
Those bodhisattvas, by this cause and condition, perfect this aspect.

If they diligently cultivate and practice, they will be able to realize it.

In order to make this stage complete,
one diligently cultivates and practices, and is able to realize
that the bodhisattvas, by these causes and conditions, this stage is complete.
But they are still unable to attain the marvelous wisdom and marvelous insight that are unobstructed and unattached to all knowable realms.

In order to make this stage complete,
one diligently cultivates and practices, and is able to realize
by these causes and conditions, this stage is complete. Because this stage is complete,

Good man!
You should know that these eleven stages universally encompass all stages.
World-Honored One!
Why is the first stage called the Ground of Extreme Joy?
Up to why is it called the Buddha Ground?
Good man!
Accomplishing great meaning, attaining the unprecedented, giving rise to the supramundane mind, giving rise to great joy.
Therefore, the first is called the ground of extreme joy.
Far away from all subtle transgressions of the precepts.
Therefore, the second is called the ground of freedom from defilements.
Because the samÄdhi and dhÄraá¹‡Ä« of retention obtained by them can serve as the basis for immeasurable wisdom-light.
Therefore, the third is called the ground of radiating light.
Because the factors of enlightenment obtained by them
Burn afflictions with wisdom like a flame.
Therefore, the fourth is called the ground of flaming wisdom.
Because the skillful cultivation of those very factors of enlightenment is extremely difficult and only attained with mastery.
Therefore, the fifth is called the ground of utmost difficulty to conquer.
Directly observing the flow and transformation of all conditioned phenomena.
And because the attention focused on the signless often appears before one.
Therefore, the sixth is called the ground of direct presence.
Able to enter far and perfectly into the signless attention without interruption.
Neighboring the ground of purity.
Therefore, the seventh is called the ground of far-reaching.
Because they attain effortless [practice] with regard to signlessness.
They are not moved by the manifest afflictions with regard to various signs.
Therefore, the eighth is called the Immovable Ground.
With mastery in teaching the Dharma in all ways,
They attain immeasurable vast wisdom.
Therefore, the ninth is called the Ground of Excellent Wisdom.
The body of coarseness is vast like space, and the Dharma body is perfect.
It is like a great cloud that can completely cover [everything].
Therefore, the tenth is called the Cloud of Dharma Ground.
Permanently severing the most subtle afflictions and the obstacles to knowledge, without attachment and without obstruction,
Manifesting perfect enlightenment with regard to all kinds of knowable objects.
Therefore, the eleventh is called the Buddha Ground.
World-Honored One,
In these grounds, how many kinds of foolishness are there?
How many kinds of coarseness are there?
What are they the antidotes to?
Good man,
In these grounds, there are twenty-two kinds of foolishness,
Eleven kinds of coarseness,
Which are the antidotes to.
That is to say, in the first ground there are two kinds of ignorance.
First, the ignorance of attachment to the individual and dharmas.
Second, the ignorance of the defilements of the evil destinies.
And the coarseness that serves as their antidote.
In the second ground there are two kinds of ignorance.
First, the ignorance of subtle transgressions.
Second, the ignorance of the various destinies of karma.
And the coarseness that serves as their antidote.
In the third ground there are two kinds of ignorance.
First, the ignorance of desire and greed.
Second, the ignorance of the dhÄraá¹‡Ä« of perfect retention of what is heard.
And the coarseness that serves as their antidote.
In the fourth ground there are two kinds of ignorance.
First, the ignorance of attachment to meditative absorption.
Second, the ignorance of attachment to the Dharma.
And the coarseness that serves as their antidote.
In the fifth ground there are two kinds of ignorance.ğŸ”½First, the ignorance of unilaterally intending to abandon saá¹ƒsÄra.
Second, the ignorance of unilaterally intending to proceed towards nirvÄá¹‡a.
and their coarseness as the objects to be eliminated.
In the sixth ground, there are two kinds of ignorance.
The first is the ignorance of directly observing the transmigration of all conditioned phenomena.
The second is the ignorance of the frequent manifestation of characteristics.
And their coarseness as the objects to be eliminated.
In the seventh ground, there are two kinds of ignorance.
The first is the ignorance of the subtle manifestation of characteristics.
The second is the ignorance of the skillful means of single-pointed attention to the signless.
And their coarseness as the objects to be eliminated.
In the eighth ground, there are two kinds of ignorance.
The first is the ignorance of making effort in the signless.
The second is the ignorance of mastery over characteristics.

The second is foolishness in penetrating subtle and secret matters.
And their coarseness as the objects to be counteracted.
In the stage of a TathÄgata, there are two kinds of foolishness.

The second is foolishness in the extremely subtle obstructions.

Good son!
Because of these twenty-two kinds of foolishness,

And one attains supreme, perfect enlightenment.
Free from those bonds.
World-Honored One!
Supreme, perfect enlightenment is extremely rare,
and even attains great benefits and great fruits.
It enables bodhisattvas to break through such a great net of foolishness.
One is able to transcend such a great and dense forest of heavy burdens.
One directly realizes supreme perfect enlightenment.
World-Honored One.
How many kinds of distinctions are established in these grounds?
Good man.
In brief, there are eight kinds.
First, the purity of superior intention;
second, the purity of mind;
third, the purity of compassion;
fourth, the purity of the perfections;
fifth, the purity of seeing Buddhas, making offerings, and serving them;
sixth, the purity of maturing sentient beings;
seventh, the purity of rebirth;
eighth, the purity of majestic virtue.
Good man.
The purity of superior intention up to the purity of majestic virtue in the first ground,
the purity of superior intention up to the purity of majestic virtue in the subsequent grounds up to the Buddha ground,
should be known as progressively more excellent.
Only in the Buddha ground is the purity of rebirth excluded.
Moreover, the merits possessed in the first ground
are all equally present in the subsequent grounds.
One should know that the merits of one's own ground are superior.
All the merits of the ten grounds of the bodhisattvas are still surpassable.
The merits of the Buddha ground should be known as unsurpassable.
World-Honored One.
For what causes and conditions do you say that the bodhisattvas' birth in the various existences is the most distinguished?
Good man.
For four causes and conditions.
First, it is because it is accumulated and produced by extremely pure wholesome roots.
Second, it is because it is taken by the power of deliberate selection.
Third, it is because of compassion and pity for all sentient beings.
Fourth, it is because one is able to be without defilements oneself and remove the defilements of others.
World-Honored One.
For what causes and conditions do you say that the bodhisattvas practice vast vows, wonderful vows, and superior vows?
Good man.
For four causes and conditions.
It is because the bodhisattvas are able to thoroughly understand the blissful abiding in nirvÄá¹‡a.
They are able to quickly realize it.
Yet they abandon the quick realization of blissful abiding.
Without conditions and without dependence, they give rise to the mind of great vows.
In order to benefit all sentient beings,
they endure many kinds of long-lasting great suffering.
Therefore, I say that the practices of those bodhisattvas are vast vows, wonderful vows, and supreme vows.
World-Honored One,
how many kinds of things should bodhisattvas learn?
Good man,

They are giving, upholding precepts,
endurance, vigor,

World-Honored One,

How many are included in the training of superior concentration?
How many are included in the training of superior wisdom?
Good man,

Concentration is only included in the training of superior concentration.
Wisdom is included in the training of superior wisdom.
I say that vigor is found in all [six pÄramitÄs].
World-Honored One.
Of these six kinds of things to be learned,
how many are included in the accumulation of merit,

Good man.
If they are included in the superior training in morality,
they are included in the accumulation of merit.
If they are included in the superior training in wisdom,
they are included in the accumulation of wisdom.
I say that the two of vigor and meditation pervade all.
World-Honored One.
Among these six kinds of things to be learned,
how should bodhisattvas cultivate and learn?
Good man.
You should cultivate and learn through five aspects.
First, initially in the subtle true teachings associated with the perfection of the bodhisattva canon,
have intense faith and understanding.
Second, next in the ten kinds of Dharma practices, with the wonderful wisdom accomplished through hearing, contemplation, and cultivation,
strive to practice.
Third, follow and protect the mind of enlightenment.
Fourth, to be close to true and good spiritual friends.
Fifth, to diligently cultivate wholesome practices without interruption.
World-Honored One.
For what causes and conditions do you establish such things to be learned?
Why are there only six in number?
Good man.
For two causes and conditions.
First, for the sake of benefiting all sentient beings.
Second, for the sake of counteracting all afflictions.
You should know that the first three benefit sentient beings.
The last three counteract all afflictions.
As for the first three benefiting sentient beings,
That is to say, because bodhisattvas give,
They gather resources to benefit sentient beings.
Because they uphold precepts,
They do not harm, oppress, or disturb to benefit sentient beings.
Because they are patient,
They are able to endure harm, oppression, and disturbance.
To benefit sentient beings.
As for the last three counteracting afflictions,
That is to say, because bodhisattvas are diligent,
Although they have not yet permanently subdued all afflictions and have not yet permanently eliminated all latent tendencies,
they are able to courageously cultivate wholesome practices.
Those afflictions are unable to topple the practice of wholesome activities.
Due to meditative concentration,
afflictions are permanently subdued.
Due to prajÃ±Ä,
latent tendencies are permanently eliminated.
World-Honored One,
for what causes and conditions do you establish the remaining perfections as only having four numbers?
Good sons,
they serve as companions to the previous six kinds of perfections.
That is to say, the bodhisattvas, regarding the sentient beings included in the previous three kinds of perfections,
with the skillful means of the various embracing activities,
embraces and accepts them, establishing them in wholesome practices.
Therefore, I say that the perfection of skillful means serves as a companion to the previous three kinds.
If the bodhisattvas, in the present life, due to having many afflictions,
are unable to be capable of uninterrupted cultivation,
Because of inferior aspiration and inferior resolve in the lower realms.
Inwardly abiding in the mind,
one is incapable.
Because one is unable to hear and cultivate well the bodhisattva canon,
one is unable to give rise to supramundane wisdom through meditative absorption.
One then accepts a small and inferior accumulation of merit and virtue.
For the future, one reduces afflictions
and gives rise to correct vows.
This is called the perfection of vows.
By means of these vows,
one is able to cultivate effort with reduced afflictions.
Therefore I say that the perfection of vows assists the perfection of effort.
If bodhisattvas associate with good spiritual friends,
listen to the true Dharma,
and contemplate it correctly,
because of these causes and conditions,
they transform inferior aspirations into superior aspirations

This is called the perfection of power.
By the power of this, one has the ability to abide in the mind within.
Therefore, I say that the perfection of power is the companion of the perfection of meditation.ğŸ”½If bodhisattvas,
having already been able to hear the bodhisattva canon, cultivate it well, they can give rise to meditation.
This is called the perfection of wisdom.
By means of this wisdom,
one is able to give rise to supramundane wisdom.
Therefore, I say that the perfection of wisdom is the companion of the perfection of wisdom.
World-Honored One,
what are the causes and conditions for expounding the six perfections in this order?
Good man,
it is because they can serve as the basis for the subsequent [perfections].
That is to say, if bodhisattvas are not concerned with their bodies or wealth,
they will be able to uphold the pure precepts.
In order to protect the precepts, they will cultivate patience.ğŸ”½Having cultivated patience, they will be able to give rise to diligence.
Having given rise to diligence, they will be able to accomplish meditation.
Having perfected meditation, one is then able to attain supramundane wisdom.
Therefore, I explain the sequence of the perfections in this way.
World-Honored One,
how many kinds of distinctions are there in each of these six perfections?
Good son,
each has three kinds.
The three kinds of giving are:
first, the giving of Dharma;
second, the giving of material wealth;
third, the giving of fearlessness.
The three kinds of precepts are:
first, the precept of turning away from unwholesomeness;
second, the precept of giving rise to wholesome dharmas;
third, the precept of giving rise to benefiting sentient beings.
The three kinds of patience are:
first, the patience of enduring harm from others;
second, the patience of peacefully enduring suffering;
third, the patience of contemplating the truth of dharmas.
The three kinds of vigor are:
first, the vigor of donning armor;
second, the vigor of practice in giving rise to wholesome dharmas;
third, the vigor of practice in benefiting sentient beings.
The three kinds of meditation are:

First, the concentration of dwelling in tranquility, which is the antidote to afflictions and various sufferings, due to being free from discrimination, peaceful, extremely peaceful, and free from faults.
Second, the concentration of attracting merits.
Third, the concentration of attracting the benefit of sentient beings.
As for the three kinds of wisdom,ğŸ”½first, the wisdom that takes conventional truths as its object.
Second, the wisdom that takes ultimate truths as its object.
Third, the wisdom that takes benefiting sentient beings as its object.
World-Honored One,
what are the causes and conditions
for calling the perfections perfections?
Good man,
it is for five reasons.
First, because of being free from defilement and attachment.
Second, because of being free from looking back with longing.
Third, because of being free from faults.
Fourth, because of being free from discrimination.
Fifth, because of correctly dedicating [merit].ğŸ”½As for being free from defilement and attachment,

As for being free from looking back with longing,
It means that in the fruits, retributions, and requitals of all perfections, the mind is unfettered.
Without offenses means
in these perfections,

Free from non-skillful practices,
without discrimination means
in these perfections,

Correct dedication means

World-Honored One,

Good son,
you should know that these matters are roughly of six kinds.
First, in the desires and pleasures of delighting in wealth and sovereignty,

Second, in the practices of indulging the body, speech, and mind according to one's desires,
one deeply sees merits and benefits.
Third, in the midst of being disdained and unable to bear it by others,
one deeply sees merits and benefits.
Fourth, in the midst of not diligently cultivating and being attached to sensual pleasures,
one deeply sees merits and benefits.
Fifth, in the midst of dwelling in a noisy and chaotic world and engaging in mixed activities,
one deeply sees merits and benefits.
Sixth, in the midst of seeing, hearing, perceiving, and knowing, and in verbal disputes,
one deeply sees merits and benefits.
World-Honored One,
what are the fruits and retributions of all these perfections?
Good son,
you should know that there are also six kinds of these.
First, attaining great wealth;
second, being reborn in a good realm;
third, having no enemies, no destruction, and much joy and happiness;
fourth, being the lord of sentient beings;
fifth, having a body free from harm;
sixth, having a great lineage.
World-Honored One,
what are called the mixed defiled dharmas of the perfections?
Good son,
It should be known that in brief, there are four kinds of practices.
First, the practice of lacking compassion.
Second, the practice of being unreasonable.
Third, the practice of being not constant.
Fourth, the practice of being not earnest.
As for the practice of being unreasonable,
it refers to when practicing the other perfections,
with regard to the other perfections,
one is far removed from loss and destruction.
World-Honored One,
what are called non-skillful practices?
Good sons,ğŸ”½when bodhisattvas benefit sentient beings through the perfections,
if they only benefit sentient beings by providing them with material goods,
and are content with that without causing them to leave unwholesome states and establish them in wholesome states,
this is called non-skillful practice.
Why is it so?
Good sons,
it is not that only doing this for sentient beings is called true benefit.
It is like excrement, whether much or little, there is no way to make it fragrant and clean.
Thus, sentient beings are by nature suffering due to the suffering of conditioned existence.
Their nature is suffering.
There is no expedient but to temporarily benefit them with wealth and make them happy.
Only by placing them in the wonderful and good Dharma

World-Honored One,
how many kinds of purity do all these perfections have?
Good son,
I never say that the perfections have any other purity apart from these five aspects.
However, I will now, based on these matters,
generally and specifically explain the characteristics of the purity of the perfections.
As for the general explanation of the characteristics of the purity of all the perfections,
it should be known as being of seven kinds.
What are the seven?
First, the bodhisattva does not seek to be known by others regarding these dharmas.
Second, having seen these dharmas, he does not give rise to attachment.
Third, he does not give rise to doubt regarding these dharmas,

Fourth, they never praise themselves or disparage others, or look down on anyone.
Fifth, they never become arrogant or indulge in self-indulgence.
Sixth, they never become content with little attainment.
Seventh, they never give rise to jealousy or stinginess towards others because of these dharmas.
As for the characteristics of the purification of all perfections,
there are also seven kinds.
What are the seven?
Namely, the seven characteristics of pure giving as taught by the bodhisattvas.
They practice in accordance with them.
First, by the purity of the objects of giving,
one practices pure giving.
Second, by the purity of precepts,
one practices pure giving.
Third, by the purity of views,
one practices pure giving.
Fourth, by the purity of mind,
one practices pure giving.
Fifth, by the purity of speech,
one practices pure giving.
Sixth, by the purity of wisdom,
one practices pure giving.
Seventh, by the purity of freedom from defilements,
Practicing pure giving.
These are called the seven characteristics of pure giving.
Moreover, all bodhisattvas are able to thoroughly understand all the precepts established for training.

They are able to thoroughly understand the transgression of leaving, and possess the precepts of permanence, the precepts of solidity, the precepts of constant practice, and the precepts of constant turning.
They accept and study all the precepts.
These are called the seven characteristics of pure precepts.
If all bodhisattvas deeply give rise to faith in the ripening of their own karmic fruits,
when all the present unfavorable events
do not give rise to anger,
do not speak back in anger,ğŸ”½are not angry, do not hit,
do not frighten, do not mock,
do not harm each other with various unfavorable things,
do not harbor grudges,
when admonishing do not cause anger and distress,
and also do not wait for others to come and admonish,
do not practice patience out of fear or with a defiled mind,
Do not abandon them because of past kindness.
This is called the seven kinds of pure aspects of patience.
If bodhisattvas thoroughly penetrate the nature of equality of vigor,
Not by being courageous and diligent,
They exalt themselves and look down on others.
Endowed with great power and great vigor,
They are capable of enduring.
Firm and courageous,
They never abandon the yoke of wholesome dharmas.
This is called the seven kinds of pure aspects of vigor.
If bodhisattvas have the samÄdhi and dhyÄna that thoroughly penetrate characteristics,ğŸ”½They have perfect samÄdhi and dhyÄna,
They have complete samÄdhi and dhyÄna,ğŸ”½They have the samÄdhi and dhyÄna of progress,
They have the samÄdhi and dhyÄna of no support,
They have the samÄdhi and dhyÄna of good cultivation,
They have the immeasurable samÄdhi and dhyÄna cultivated through hearing and contemplating the bodhisattva canon,
This is called the seven kinds of pure aspects of dhyÄna.
If bodhisattvas are able to avoid the two extremes of reification and nihilism,
and practice the middle way,
this is called wisdom.
By means of this wisdom,
one can truly understand the meaning of the gates of liberation.
That is, the three gates of liberation of emptiness, wishlessness, and signlessness.
One can truly understand the meaning of having intrinsic nature.ğŸ”½That is, the three kinds of intrinsic nature of the imagined,ğŸ”½the other-dependent,
and the perfected.
One can truly understand the meaning of having no intrinsic nature.
That is, the three kinds of natures that lack intrinsic nature of characteristics, arising, and ultimate reality.
One can truly understand the meaning of the conventional truth.
That is, the five fields of knowledge.
One can truly understand the meaning of the ultimate truth.
That is, the seven kinds of suchness.
Moreover, being free from discrimination and free from all conceptual proliferation,
dwelling for the most part in the single principle,
taking immeasurable general dharmas as objects,
and practicing vipaÅ›yanÄ,
one is able to well accomplish the practice in accordance with the Dharma.
These are called the seven kinds of pure characteristics of wisdom.
World-Honored One.
What are the functions of these five characteristics?
Good man.
You should know that those characteristics have five functions.
That is, because bodhisattvas are free from defilement,
in the present life, regarding the perfections they cultivate,
they always earnestly and diligently apply themselves,ğŸ”½without negligence.
Because they do not cling,
they accept the causes of non-negligence in the future.
Because they are without fault, they are able to cultivate and practice extremely well,ğŸ”½extremely perfectly,ğŸ”½extremely purely,
and extremely brightly the perfections.
Because they are without discrimination,
the perfection of skillful means is quickly perfected.
Because they are correctly dedicated,
in all their rebirths, the perfections and their desirable fruits and retributions
are inexhaustible, up to unsurpassed perfect enlightenment.
World-Honored One.
As for these perfections that have been explained,
Which is the most vast?
Which is the most undefiled?
Which is the most radiant?
Which is unshakable?
Which is the most pure?
Good man!ğŸ”½The nature of non-attachment,
the nature of non-regard,
the nature of correct dedication,
are the most vast.
The nature of non-transgression,
the nature of non-discrimination,
the nature of non-defiled deliberation and action,
are the most radiant.
Those who have entered the stage of non-retrogression,
are called unshakable.
Those included in the ten grounds and the Buddha ground,
are called the most pure.
World-Honored One,
what are the causes and conditions
for the bodhisattvas' attainment of the fruits of the perfections,
and their various retributions,
